title: Exodus Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Exodus chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Exodus Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Exodus Chapter 8.

questions.question: Who did the LORD instruct to go to Pharaoh and tell him to let the Israelites go?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:1 states, 'And the LORD spake unto Moses, Go unto Pharaoh, and say unto him...' showing Moses was instructed.

questions.question: What plague did the LORD threaten if Pharaoh refused to let the people go?
questions.correctAnswer: Frogs
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:2 says, 'I will smite all thy borders with frogs', indicating the plague of frogs.

questions.question: Where did the frogs come into according to Exodus 8:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Houses, bedchambers, ovens, kneadingtroughs
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:3 details the frogs entering homes, beds, ovens, and kneading troughs.

questions.question: Who stretched out his hand with the rod over the waters of Egypt to bring forth frogs?
questions.correctAnswer: Aaron
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:6 states, 'And Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt; and the frogs came up...'

questions.question: True or False: The magicians were able to bring forth lice by their enchantments.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:18 says the magicians could not bring forth lice by their enchantments.

questions.question: What did the magicians say when they could not replicate the plague of lice?
options: This is the finger of God
This is the work of the devil
questions.correctAnswer: This is the finger of God
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:19 states, 'Then the magicians said unto Pharaoh, This is the finger of God.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Exodus 8:21 says, 'Else, if thou wilt not let my people go, behold, I will send ______ upon thee, and upon thy servants, and upon thy people.'
questions.correctAnswer: swarms of flies
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:21 clearly mentions sending swarms of flies if Pharaoh refuses to let the people go.

questions.question: Which land was spared from the swarms of flies?
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Goshen
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:22 states, 'I will sever in that day the land of Goshen... that no swarms of flies shall be there.'

questions.question: True or False: Pharaoh agreed immediately to let the people go after the plague of frogs was removed.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:15 tells that Pharaoh hardened his heart and did not let the people go after the frogs were removed.

questions.question: What did Moses request Pharaoh to allow the Israelites to do three days’ journey into the wilderness?
options: Sacrifice to the LORD their God
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifice to the LORD their God
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:27 says, 'We will go three days' journey into the wilderness, and sacrifice to the LORD our God.'

questions.question: Who hardened his heart after the removal of the swarms of flies and refused to let the people go?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:32 states, 'And Pharaoh hardened his heart at this time also, neither would he let the people go.'

questions.question: True or False: The LORD caused the dust of the land to become lice throughout all Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:17 confirms that the dust became lice throughout all the land of Egypt.

questions.question: What did the people of Egypt gather to heaps after the frogs died?
questions.correctAnswer: Dead frogs
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:14 says, 'And they gathered them together upon heaps: and the land stank,' referring to dead frogs.

questions.question: What did Pharaoh ask Moses and Aaron to do after the flies came into Egypt?
options: Go sacrifice to their God in the land
questions.correctAnswer: Go sacrifice to their God in the land
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:25 records Pharaoh calling Moses and Aaron saying, 'Go ye, sacrifice to your God in the land.'

questions.question: What did Moses say was not meet to do in Pharaoh’s land regarding the sacrifices?
options: Sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:26 explains Moses' concern about sacrificing the abomination of the Egyptians before their eyes.

medium.title: Exodus Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Exodus Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged because their prayers seem unanswered when facing trials. Based on Exodus 8, what biblical truth about prayer and God's timing would you share?
options: God answers prayers according to His perfect plan and timing
God always answers immediately without delay
God only answers prayers if we are perfect
questions.correctAnswer: God answers prayers according to His perfect plan and timing
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:8-10 shows Pharaoh asking Moses to pray to remove the frogs, and Moses agreeing to pray the next day, demonstrating that God's answers come according to His timing. Also, Exodus 8:12-13 shows Moses praying and God removing the frogs. This teaches patience and trust in God's sovereign timing.

questions.question: How does Exodus 8 demonstrate the importance of obedience to God's commands in the life of a believer?
options: Pharaoh's refusal to obey led to worsening plagues
Pharaoh obeyed immediately and was blessed
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh's refusal to obey led to worsening plagues
questions.explanation: Throughout Exodus 8, particularly in verses 15 and 32, Pharaoh hardened his heart and refused to obey God's command to let the people go, which caused more plagues. This shows the consequence of disobedience and the blessing of trusting and obeying God.

questions.question: What can Exodus 8 teach about God's care and protection for His people even amid trials?
options: God protected the land of Goshen from the swarm of flies
God allowed all His people to suffer equally
God abandoned His people during the plagues
God punished only Moses and Aaron
questions.correctAnswer: God protected the land of Goshen from the swarm of flies
questions.explanation: In Exodus 8:22, God promised to sever the land of Goshen, where His people dwelt, so that no swarms of flies would be there. This shows God's protective care for His people even during judgments.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness and hardness of heart after facing difficulties. Based on Exodus 8, what biblical principle about humility and repentance would you share?
options: Hardening the heart leads to prolonged suffering
questions.correctAnswer: Hardening the heart leads to prolonged suffering
questions.explanation: Pharaoh repeatedly hardened his heart (Exodus 8:15, 8:19, 8:32), refusing to repent and obey God, which resulted in continued plagues. This teaches the danger of a hardened heart and the need for humility and repentance.

questions.question: How does Exodus 8 encourage believers to witness God's power and faithfulness to others?
options: By showing that no one is like the LORD our God
By denying God's involvement in trials
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that no one is like the LORD our God
questions.explanation: In Exodus 8:10, Moses says, 'that thou mayest know that there is none like unto the LORD our God,' emphasizing God's unique power as a testimony to others. This encourages believers to share God's faithfulness boldly.

questions.question: What does Exodus 8 teach about the role of intercessory prayer for others?
options: Moses interceded for Egypt to remove the plagues
Prayer is only for personal needs
questions.correctAnswer: Moses interceded for Egypt to remove the plagues
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:12 and 8:30 show Moses praying to the LORD to remove the frogs and flies, interceding on behalf of Pharaoh and Egypt. This exemplifies the biblical call to intercede for others.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to use dishonest means to achieve goals. Based on Exodus 8, what biblical truth about integrity and trust in God would you share?
options: Pharaoh’s deceit led to harsher consequences
God approves dishonesty if it benefits you
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh’s deceit led to harsher consequences
questions.explanation: In Exodus 8:29, Moses warns Pharaoh not to deal deceitfully in not letting the people go. Pharaoh’s continued deceit resulted in further plagues and hardening of his heart (Exodus 8:32). This teaches the importance of honesty and trusting God's provision.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 8, the magicians were able to replicate all of the plagues that God sent upon Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: In Exodus 8:7, magicians replicated the frogs with their enchantments, but in Exodus 8:18, they could not replicate the lice, showing the limits of human power compared to God's sovereignty.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 8 shows that God disciplines those who oppose His will but also provides opportunities for repentance.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Throughout Exodus 8, God sends plagues as discipline (e.g., frogs, lice, flies) but also provides Pharaoh chances to repent and release the people (Exodus 8:8, 8:28-29). This reflects God’s justice and mercy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Exodus 8, Moses told Pharaoh, 'Let my people go, that they may ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: serve me
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:1 records God's command to Moses to tell Pharaoh, 'Let my people go, that they may serve me,' emphasizing the purpose of their release to worship God.

questions.question: How does Exodus 8 illustrate the importance of perseverance through trials in the Christian life?
options: Despite repeated plagues, Moses and Aaron continued to obey and trust God
Moses gave up after the first plague
Pharaoh immediately relented after the first sign
questions.correctAnswer: Despite repeated plagues, Moses and Aaron continued to obey and trust God
questions.explanation: Moses and Aaron faithfully carry out God's commands, even when Pharaoh resists (Exodus 8:6, 8:16-17, 8:30), demonstrating perseverance and obedience during hardship.

questions.question: What biblical principle about stewardship and responsibility does Exodus 8 teach through the plagues affecting Egypt's environment?
options: God holds nations accountable for their actions, affecting their land and resources
Natural disasters happen randomly without cause
God only cares about individuals, not nations
questions.correctAnswer: God holds nations accountable for their actions, affecting their land and resources
questions.explanation: The plagues of frogs, lice, and flies (Exodus 8:2-7, 8:16-24) show that God exercises judgment on Egypt as a nation, impacting their environment, which implies responsibility and stewardship at national and personal levels.

questions.question: How does Exodus 8 encourage believers to maintain faith and trust in God despite opposition?
options: By showing God's power over Pharaoh's resistance and eventual judgment
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God's power over Pharaoh's resistance and eventual judgment
questions.explanation: Exodus 8 chronicles Pharaoh's resistance despite God's mighty signs (Exodus 8:15, 8:32), but God's sovereignty prevails, encouraging believers to trust God amidst opposition.

questions.question: What does Exodus 8 teach about the importance of worship and honoring God in family and community life?
options: God's people were released to serve and sacrifice to Him
questions.correctAnswer: God's people were released to serve and sacrifice to Him
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:1 and 8:25-27 show the purpose of letting the Israelites go was to serve and sacrifice to the LORD, highlighting worship as a vital part of family and community life.

questions.question: How does Exodus 8 model humility in approaching God during difficulties?
options: Moses and Aaron consistently obey and seek God’s help through prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Moses and Aaron consistently obey and seek God’s help through prayer
questions.explanation: In Exodus 8:5-6 and 8:12, Moses and Aaron obey God's commands and pray to Him, showing humility and dependence on God during trials.

hard.title: Exodus Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Exodus Chapter 8.

questions.question: In Exodus 8, what is the significance of Pharaoh's repeated hardening of his heart after each plague?
options: It demonstrates human stubbornness against divine will
It shows Pharaoh's repentance and change of heart
It symbolizes the failure of the Egyptian gods
It indicates Moses' lack of faith
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates human stubbornness against divine will
questions.explanation: Pharaoh's hardening of his heart, as mentioned in Exodus 8:15 and 8:32, highlights the theme of human resistance to God's commands, which is crucial for the unfolding of the divine plan.

questions.question: Which plague in Exodus 8 is directly associated with the Hebrew term 'arov', often translated as 'swarms'?
questions.correctAnswer: Swarms of flies
questions.explanation: The term 'arov' appears in Exodus 8:21-24 and refers to the swarms of flies sent by God, distinguishing this plague from others like frogs or lice.

questions.question: How does the plague of frogs in Exodus 8 foreshadow later biblical themes of judgment and redemption?
options: The frogs symbolize chaos overcoming order, later redeemed by God's intervention
The frogs represent Egyptian gods destroyed by Moses
The frogs prefigure the baptismal cleansing in the New Testament
The frogs are a direct punishment for idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: The frogs symbolize chaos overcoming order, later redeemed by God's intervention
questions.explanation: Frogs covering the land (Exodus 8:2-6) symbolize disorder invading Egypt, which is later resolved by God's power, illustrating a pattern of judgment followed by deliverance seen throughout Scripture.

questions.question: Which Old Testament book contains a similar motif of divine plagues as a demonstration of God's power, paralleling Exodus 8?
questions.correctAnswer: Joshua
questions.explanation: The book of Joshua references the plagues of Egypt (Joshua 24:6) as God's acts to deliver Israel, showing intertextual connections with Exodus 8's plagues.

questions.question: What is the literary structure used in Exodus 8 to present each plague and Pharaoh's reaction?
options: Chiasm with alternating divine command and human response
Parallelism between Egyptian gods and plagues
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm with alternating divine command and human response
questions.explanation: Exodus 8 employs a chiastic structure where God's command is followed by the plague, Pharaoh's reaction, and Moses' intercession, emphasizing the narrative rhythm.

questions.question: What was unique about the magicians' response to the plague of lice compared to the plague of frogs?
options: They could not replicate the plague of lice
They only replicated the plague of lice
They denied the existence of the plagues
questions.correctAnswer: They could not replicate the plague of lice
questions.explanation: In Exodus 8:18, the magicians failed to bring forth lice by their enchantments, unlike with frogs, signifying divine superiority.

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Egypt, why would the plague of flies, sparing Goshen, be particularly humiliating for Pharaoh?
options: It showed God's protection over Israel and exposed Egyptian vulnerability
It was a common natural occurrence in Egypt
It represented a blessing to the Egyptian gods
It was a sign of Pharaoh's strength
questions.correctAnswer: It showed God's protection over Israel and exposed Egyptian vulnerability
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:22 describes the land of Goshen being spared, highlighting the distinction between God's people and Egyptians, undermining Pharaoh's authority.

questions.question: What typological significance does Aaron's rod stretching over the waters in Exodus 8:5-6 have in later biblical narratives?
options: It foreshadows the rod used to part the Red Sea
It represents the Ark of the Covenant
It prefigures the resurrection of Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the rod used to part the Red Sea
questions.explanation: Aaron's rod is a symbol of God's power working through Moses' leadership, anticipating its use in the Red Sea crossing (Exodus 14).

questions.question: How does the dialogue between Moses and Pharaoh in Exodus 8 reflect ancient Near Eastern treaty negotiation patterns?
options: It mirrors demands, refusals, and conditional agreements
It shows a peaceful resolution with no conflict
It depicts Pharaoh as the sole decision-maker without negotiation
It uses poetic lamentation typical of treaties
questions.correctAnswer: It mirrors demands, refusals, and conditional agreements
questions.explanation: The interactions, such as Pharaoh's conditional promises (Exodus 8:28), resemble treaty rhetoric common in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Exodus 8:16-17, Aaron smote the dust of the land and it became ______ throughout Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: lice
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:16-17 states that the dust became lice on man and beast, marking the third plague.

questions.question: True or False: The plague of frogs was the first plague where Pharaoh asked Moses to pray for relief and promised to let the people go immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:8 records Pharaoh requesting Moses and Aaron to entreat the LORD to remove the frogs, offering to let the people go to sacrifice.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the finger of God' used by the magicians in Exodus 8:19?
options: It acknowledges divine power beyond human magic
It refers to a specific Egyptian deity
It means the plague was a coincidence
It is a term for Pharaoh's authority
questions.correctAnswer: It acknowledges divine power beyond human magic
questions.explanation: The magicians' statement in Exodus 8:19 admits that the lice plague is an act of God, highlighting the limits of their own powers.

questions.question: How does the plague narrative in Exodus 8 contribute to the overall theme of God's sovereignty in the Pentateuch?
options: By demonstrating God's control over nature and human affairs
By showing the futility of worshipping Yahweh
By emphasizing human wisdom over divine power
By illustrating the randomness of natural disasters
questions.correctAnswer: By demonstrating God's control over nature and human affairs
questions.explanation: The plagues in Exodus 8 reveal God's sovereign authority over Egypt, Pharaoh, and creation, reinforcing a central Pentateuch theme.

questions.question: Which New Testament event can be seen as a typological fulfillment of the Exodus plagues, particularly the liberation theme seen in Exodus 8?
options: The Pentecost outpouring of the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: The Pentecost outpouring of the Spirit
questions.explanation: The liberation of Israel from Egypt through the plagues prefigures the new freedom and empowerment given through the Holy Spirit at Pentecost.

questions.question: Why did Moses refuse Pharaoh's initial offer to sacrifice to the LORD in the land of Egypt, according to Exodus 8:26?
options: Because sacrificing Egyptian abominations would anger the people
Because Moses wanted to sacrifice only in Jerusalem
Because Moses was afraid of Pharaoh
questions.correctAnswer: Because sacrificing Egyptian abominations would anger the people
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:26 explains Moses' concern that sacrificing Egyptian idols would provoke the Egyptians to stone them.

theological.title: Exodus Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Exodus Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason God commands Pharaoh to let the Israelites go according to Exodus 8?
options: So they may serve the LORD
So they can conquer other nations
questions.correctAnswer: So they may serve the LORD
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:1 states that the LORD commands Moses to tell Pharaoh to let His people go so that they may serve Him. This aligns with God's desire for His people to worship and serve Him (Deuteronomy 6:13; Joshua 24:15; John 4:23-24; Romans 12:1).

questions.question: What plague did God send after Pharaoh refused to let the Israelites go, as described in Exodus 8?
questions.correctAnswer: Frogs
questions.explanation: God sent frogs to cover the land of Egypt as a judgment when Pharaoh refused to release the Israelites (Exodus 8:2-6). This plague demonstrated God's power over creation and challenged Egyptian deities (Exodus 8:7; Psalm 78:44; Hebrews 11:28).

questions.question: Who was instructed to stretch out his hand with the rod to bring forth frogs upon Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Aaron
questions.explanation: God commanded Moses to tell Aaron to stretch out his rod over the waters to bring forth frogs (Exodus 8:5-6). Aaron acts as God's appointed mediator, foreshadowing Christ as the high priest interceding for the people (Hebrews 4:14-16; Hebrews 7:23-28).

questions.question: What was Pharaoh’s initial response after the frogs covered Egypt?
options: He asked Moses and Aaron to pray to the LORD to remove the frogs
He immediately let the Israelites go
questions.correctAnswer: He asked Moses and Aaron to pray to the LORD to remove the frogs
questions.explanation: Pharaoh called Moses and Aaron to entreat the LORD to remove the frogs, promising to let the people go to sacrifice (Exodus 8:8). This reveals Pharaoh’s temporary submission but also his hardened heart (Exodus 8:15; Romans 9:17-18; Revelation 16:9).

questions.question: After God removed the frogs, what was Pharaoh’s response according to Exodus 8?
options: He hardened his heart and would not let the people go
He sought a treaty with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He hardened his heart and would not let the people go
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:15 records that Pharaoh hardened his heart again despite the respite, refusing to obey God’s command. This hardness illustrates human rebellion and God’s sovereign judgment (Exodus 8:15, 32; Romans 1:18-32; John 12:37-40).

questions.question: What new plague did God send after the frogs, as described in Exodus 8?
questions.correctAnswer: Lice
questions.explanation: God instructed Aaron to strike the dust, which became lice over all the land (Exodus 8:16-17). This plague demonstrated God's power beyond the magicians, who could not replicate it (Exodus 8:18-19), affirming God's unique sovereignty (Isaiah 45:7; Psalm 135:6).

questions.question: Why could the Egyptian magicians not replicate the plague of lice?
options: It was the finger of God
questions.correctAnswer: It was the finger of God
questions.explanation: The magicians acknowledged that the lice plague was beyond their power, calling it 'the finger of God' (Exodus 8:19). This phrase implies divine intervention and manifests God's supremacy over human attempts to mimic His works (Luke 11:20; Psalm 8:3-4; Isaiah 40:12).

questions.question: What distinction did God make concerning the land of Goshen during the plague of flies?
options: No swarms of flies shall be there
It would be the first to suffer
questions.correctAnswer: No swarms of flies shall be there
questions.explanation: God promised to sever the land of Goshen so that no flies would be there, marking a clear distinction between His people and Egypt (Exodus 8:22). This separation points to God's protective covenant with His people (Exodus 12:12; Psalm 91:3-7; John 10:27-29).

questions.question: How did the land of Egypt respond to the grievous swarm of flies?
options: The land was corrupted by reason of the swarm of flies
The crops flourished despite the flies
The flies only affected Pharaoh’s house
questions.correctAnswer: The land was corrupted by reason of the swarm of flies
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:24 describes that the land was corrupted due to the flies, signifying a moral and physical defilement as judgment (Isaiah 24:4-6; Jeremiah 4:23-26; Revelation 8:7). This demonstrates the consequences of sin and rebellion against God.

questions.question: What was Moses’ reason for refusing to sacrifice in the land of Egypt as requested by Pharaoh?
options: They would sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians
It was too far from the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They would sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians
questions.explanation: Moses explained that sacrificing in Egypt would mean offering abominations to the LORD before the Egyptians, risking being stoned (Exodus 8:26). This underscores the holiness of God and the need for purity in worship (Leviticus 18:24-30; Hebrews 12:28-29; 1 Corinthians 10:20-21).

questions.question: What condition did Pharaoh place on the Israelites' departure to sacrifice to the LORD?
options: They should not go very far away and should intreat for him
They must leave immediately without provisions
They should leave only the men
questions.correctAnswer: They should not go very far away and should intreat for him
questions.explanation: Pharaoh allowed them to go to sacrifice but not far away and asked them to pray for him (Exodus 8:28). This shows Pharaoh’s partial concession but continued reluctance (Nehemiah 4:1-2; Acts 12:5; James 5:16).

questions.question: How did God respond to Moses' intercession for Pharaoh regarding the flies?
options: God removed the swarms of flies completely
questions.correctAnswer: God removed the swarms of flies completely
questions.explanation: After Moses prayed, the LORD removed the flies entirely from Pharaoh and Egypt (Exodus 8:31). This demonstrates God’s mercy and responsiveness to intercession (2 Chronicles 7:14; Psalm 34:17; James 5:16).

questions.question: Despite the removal of flies, what was Pharaoh’s response regarding letting the Israelites go?
options: He hardened his heart and refused to let them go
He asked for a peace treaty
questions.correctAnswer: He hardened his heart and refused to let them go
questions.explanation: Exodus 8:32 shows Pharaoh hardened his heart again, refusing to release the Israelites. This portrays the persistent rebellion of man against God’s will (Exodus 8:15; Romans 9:18; John 12:40).

questions.question: What theological truth is demonstrated by God hardening Pharaoh’s heart repeatedly in Exodus 8?
options: God’s sovereign control over human decisions
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign control over human decisions
questions.explanation: God hardening Pharaoh’s heart illustrates divine sovereignty over human will to accomplish His purposes (Exodus 8:15,32; Romans 9:17-18; Isaiah 10:5-7; John 19:11). It shows that God’s justice and mercy operate in harmony with His control over history.

questions.question: What does the plague of frogs in Exodus 8 signify about God's power in relation to Egyptian religious beliefs?
options: God’s supremacy over Egyptian deities associated with water and fertility
questions.correctAnswer: God’s supremacy over Egyptian deities associated with water and fertility
questions.explanation: The plague of frogs challenged Egyptian gods like Heket, goddess of fertility and frogs (Exodus 8:2-7). This demonstrates Yahweh’s authority over nature and false gods (Exodus 12:12; Isaiah 46:9-11; Psalm 115:4-8; 1 Corinthians 8:4-6).

questions.question: How does Exodus 8 contribute to the doctrine of God’s holiness and justice?
options: By showing God’s righteous judgment on sin and rebellion
By showing God’s approval of evil
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God’s righteous judgment on sin and rebellion
questions.explanation: The plagues in Exodus 8 reveal God's holiness and justice as He judges Egypt's oppression and Pharaoh's rebellion (Exodus 8:15,32; Leviticus 19:2; Romans 1:18; Hebrews 12:29). God's actions uphold His moral perfection and the consequences of sin.
